title: Business lending picks up at last
text:

Wed, Sep 30, 2015, 06:29 BST - UK Markets open in 1 hr 31 mins Business lending picks up at last By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 14 hours ago 
Banks are lending more to firms while mortgage borrowing is also on the rise 
Bank lending to businesses rose last month as the economy picked up and confidence grew. 
Non-financial companies borrowed £15.9bn from banks in August, up from £14.8bn in the same month of 2014, as lenders became increasingly willing to offer loans to businesses. 
At the same, time debt repayments edged up only slightly, meaning net lending increased by £1.3bn in the month, according to the data from the Bank of England. 
Britain’s small businesses borrowed an additional £233m in the month, while big companies took out loans worth £1.1bn. 
Economists took heart from the numbers, which they say could contribute to increased investment in the UK. 
“It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is vitally important for the UK’s ability to generate sustained balanced growth and to lift productivity that all companies who are in decent shape and who do want to borrow can do so, and at a non-punishing interest rate,” said Howard Archer, chief economist at IHS Global Insight. 
He added that many UK businesses have benefitted from low oil and commodity prices, which have beefed up their margins and improved profitability and cash savings, making them sound investments for lenders. 
"A number of business have been upgrading or replacing capacity and investing in processes aimed at cutting costs and boosting efficiency, and there could well be a mounting need to add capacity over the rest of 2015 and during 2016," he said. 
The Bank of England numbers also show another surge in residential mortgage lending in August. 
Home lending hit £19.1bn in the month, up from £16.9bn in August of 2014, in part driven by borrowers who were keen to lock in cheap deals before the Bank of England hikes interest rates - a move which could happen in the next 12 months. 
“Falling mortgage rates mean both new buyers and existing homeowners stand to make significant savings by locking into one of the current deals on the market,” said Brian Murphy from brokerage the Mortgage Advice Bureau. 
“This time of year often sees an influx of competitively priced products as lenders adjust their offering based on end-of-year targets, so it’s likely borrowers will continue to benefit from affordable rates.”
